author: Puzzleheaded_Youth26
body:
From my perspective, it is only TOO early if you somehow know that the same $1000 that you put into Psychedelic stocks today would make more money over the next 5 years by NOT being in Psychedelics. 

How can anyone figure out that holding psychedelics from 2021 through 2025 will make less $$$ than someone paying 3x as much for the same stock in 2024, but having cash to play with for different stock until they buy back into psychedelics.  

It is easy to look back and say: "If only I'd skipped buying AOL stock and bought Apple instead."  But the reality is that none of us have crystal balls, so have to research and make the best decisions we can today. 

I must say that a buy-and-wait strategy in the psychedelics sector isn't nearly as sexy or as interesting as a high stress short-term Dogecoin or AMC investment. 

My ongoing confidence in this sector means that this is where my money is...long term.

author: 95Daphne
body:
Last Friday was definitely Omicron related and the FT article late on Monday night really hurt economically sensitive things (crude, yields, and the Dow/Russell), but if you think this entire week was Omicron related, then you are going to have to explain that -2.6% week by the Nasdaq to me.

Only way it makes sense is if you think we're headed into a December 2018 like situation as post-COVID crash, when there have been growth scares, it has outperformed (and it looked like that was going to happen again this week until that inflation comment on Tuesday). The Dow should've bounced back better this week but there are plenty of reasons why it arguably was not the story this week (same with the S&P).

And if we're heading into a December 2018 like situation, then a lot of the big guns better get moving on going lower. Apple didn't close below $160 and Google is still a fair bit higher than its October swing low.

author: RumHam1
body:
Theres a bit more uncertainty at the moment with taper changes, changes in the inflation wording, and the new variant.  Sort of reminds me of different points in time this spring where we'd have a huge red day followed right by a huge green day.

Theres definitely room to move up.  Apple is surging, chip stocks are holding their recent gains and even extending still in some cases.  A fair amount of growth stocks are sitting on or near 52 week low.

I think we may still be in for some of this type of swing - especially if reports come out that the new variant has a higher serious infection rate.

author: Freestyle7674754398
body:
Come to the conclusion that the only way to play options is to literally just play the most liquid / biggest names. 

Solely trading SPY / QQQ / AAPL / NVDA / SHOP / AMZN / IWM has worked out so much better for me than playing anything else. You're able to be so much more consistent. 

Also as someone with less than 25k in an account, I've started only ever buying plays that I think are high risk at the end of the day. That way it takes emotion out of it with regards to day trades. 

thanks for reading my blog.

author: iszir
body:
No, it buys the security itself.  So if you buy VOO, VOO has bought into the SP500, so in turn you will own the SP500 through VOO, not the individual companies.  

Here is the SP500 which VOO owns - https://finviz.com/map.ashx

They all have different holding percentages though for example (this is wrong but bear with me), AAPL is 10% of VOO holdings while something like CSX has .5% of voo holdings.

They are all weighted differently based off size of company, how vanguard thinks they will perform etc etc

Yes I use an excel spreadsheet. I haven’t used Apple Pages before, but I would have to assume they would also have a function that can pull stock data.
